Pan-Asia Internet - 2026 Outlook: Accelerating AI Adoption's Impact on Monetization & Margins

Citi Research Brian Gong C hina Vicky Wei C hina Nelson Cheung C hina Jan 5, 2026 Pan-Asia Internet 2026 Outlook: Accelerating AI Adoption’s Impact on Monetization & Margins Pan-Asia Internet Alicia Yap AC Head of Pan-Asia Internet Research alicia.yap@citi.com +852 2501-2773 Pawl Hwang K orea Tokiya Baba J apan Ferry Wong A sean Vijit Jain I ndia Keiichi Yoneshima J apan Heejin Lim K orea Josh Yang K orea See Appendix A-1 for Analyst Certification, Important Disclosures and Research Analyst Affiliations Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. on Citi's portals. Ryan Davis Asean Sanchit Chandna India

CITI’S TAKE 4-9 2 China Internet Outlook 10-23 3. India Internet Outlook 24-27 4. Korea Internet Outlook 28-31 5. Japan Internet Outlook 32-35 6. Asean Internet Outlook 36-39 Table of Contents 3

CITI’S TAKE ● 2025 performance - China’s internet sector led in 2025 with a +31% return, outpacing the US’s +20%, Korea’s +14%, SEA’s +11%, Japan’s +10%, and India’s +9.0%, while KOSPI rose +76%, HSI +28%, Nikkei +26%, S&P 500 +16% and Nifty +10%.* ● China Internet: AI Competition & Productivity Gains – In 2026, we believe China’s AI thesis is likely to be focused on: 1) recurring revs growth of cloud infra/model stack/inference token usage; 2) user traffic turf war between AI chatbots as key internet players rush to capture AI era traffic gateway for future ecosystem monetization and 3) vertical players deploying their self-trained proprietary data AI agents to stay ahead of potential disruption and seek to strengthen user engagement and monetization upside. We expect most internet companies to see improving op leverage through productivity gains from AI-assisted cost optimization, with some enjoying reacceleration of top line growth with effective AI

agent deployment. – Thanks to fast adoption of AI assistant tools, consumers are likely to realize work and lifestyle productivity improvement, which may enable more time to spend on leisure and entertainment activities. The ongoing demand for travel and online gaming fun should support stable and resilient earnings growth for OTA and gaming companies that we believe could provide good portfolio diversification offsetting higher risk of AI hype. – Our top picks: 1) Tencent, BABA - core AI plays; 2) TCOM, NTES for resilient/stable earnings growth; 3) J&T - cross-border exposure; 4) Century Huatong as A-share pick. ● India Internet: Improving Operating Margins and Unit Economics – 2026 key themes include: 1) intense competition in quick commerce to remain high while overall profitability should further improve; 2) fintech PayTm ramps up as regulatory burden eases; 3) OTA rebound insight thanks to supply-driven dynamics and sustained demand appetite; 4) auto classifieds riding macro tailwinds; and 5)

continued weakness in jobs classifieds. We expect most companies under our coverage to continue to deliver significant expansion in operating margins, primarily driven by operating leverage but also improving unit economics/contribution margins in select companies like Swiggy and Paytm. While the recent progress on labor law reforms has provided much needed clarity on the gig economy regulatory regime, we continue to expect regulatory development in 2026, including a potential change in India’s laws pertaining to multi-brand retail FDI laws. Regulatory development in fintech should also persist. Our top picks are Eternal and Makemytrip. 4 Note: * Citi Research estimates; internet sector return was calculated by averaging major internet companies’ stock price performance in 2025.

CITI’S TAKE ● Korea Internet/Gaming/Entertainment: Market Share Gains/Selective/IP Monetization – 2026 key themes include: i) growing penetration rate of ecommerce as we expect Coupang to further gain shares in both ecommerce and food delivery; ii) ChatGPT integration in Kakaotalk helps capture search behavior transition while Naver is increasing exposure of its AI-based search summary feature to defend search leadership; iii) we remain selective on gaming given structural headwinds and intensified competition in time & wallet share from non-gaming apps, continued delay of major pipeline games, while we expect AI to potentially help in games development and cost-saving; iv) K-pop growth drivers include comeback of mega IPs (BTS by HYBE, EXO by SM) and continued monetization of mega IP (BlackPink by YG); acceleration in monetization of rookie IPs such as BabyMonster (YG), Cortis (HYBE), NCT WISH (SM); and localized Ips’ successful execution in western market

(Katseye by HYBE, Girlset by JYP). Our preferred picks are Coupang for internet/ecommerce, Krafton for gaming and HYBE for K-pop entertainment. ● Japan Internet/Gaming: AI a Blessing and a Curse/Growth Driven by Global IP – 2026 key themes include: i) online ads market should remain solid, driven by video ads and staffing ads, while search ads should stagnate; ii) we expect mid-single-digit growth for ecommerce market with AI-powered recommendation to encourage purchasing while monitoring macro trends; iii) for online games, we expect catalysts to still depend on new hit titles while the spread of external payments should support increased profitability. While companies are using AI to promote efficient development, we believe profitability improvement remains at early stages. Our top picks are Recruit and Nintendo. ● ASEAN Internet: Rising Penetration Rate Drives Growth Yet Attracting Competition – 2026 key themes include: i) SEA as an AI datacenter hub should further support structural growth opportunity of

the digital economy; ii) ecommerce competition could intensify between Shopee and TikTok; iii) any bigger traction of AI chatbot assistant could threaten and disrupt ecommerce platforms; iv) early stage of pilot testing of autonomous driving technology; v) all eyes on potential market consolidation from a possible Grab/GoTo deal materializing. We like both Grab and GoTo as our ASEAN internet picks for improving operating efficiencies and potential synergies from consolidation. 5

AI cloud infra, chatbots and agents ■ In 2026, we believe China’s AI thesis is likely to be focused on: 1) recurring revs growth of cloud infra /model stack/inference token usage; 2) user traffic turf war between AI chatbots as key internet players rush to capture AI era traffic gateway for future ecosystem monetization and 3) vertical players deploying their self-trained proprietary data AI agents to stay ahead of potential disruption and seek to strengthen user engagement and monetization upside. ■ We expect most internet firms to see improving op leverage through productivity gains from AI-assisted cost optimization, with some enjoying reacceleration of top line growth with effective AI agent deployment. Investment risks ■ Geopolitical risk persists, AI supply chain constraints, muted consumption sentiment absence of stimulus policy; ongoing merchant support measures weigh on profit, lock in consumer wallet share through membership investment, intensified competition in AI apps and slowdown in capital return. Source: dataCentral, Citi Research, data as of Dec 31, 2025.

DeepSeek and Dola (by Bytedance) ranked # 3 (65mn) & 4 (56mn) and Perplexity at # 5 (48mn). Combining Dola + Doubao (206mn), Bytedance’s AI Chat ranks # 3 globally with latest total MAUs of ~262mn, a significant achievement for China AI development. (source: Sensor Tower and Questmobile) Resilient leisure & entertainment wallet spend ■ Thanks to fast adoption of AI assistant tools, consumers are likely to realize work and lifestyle productivity improvement which may enable more time to spend on leisure and entertainment activities. The ongoing demand for travel and online gaming fun should support stable and resilient earnings growth for OTA and gaming companies that we believe could provide good portfolio diversification, offsetting the higher risk of AI hype.

China Internet: Sector Top Picks ● Tencent (700 HK; Buy; TP HK$751) - Core AI Play – We have a Buy rating on Tencent with a target price of HK$751. We retain our constructive view on Tencent as the company continued to demonstrate solid execution in driving steady/sustainable top and bottom-line growth while pursuing its AI aspiration in the forefront of enterprise and user applications. Despite supply chain constraints, Tencent has not slowed its commitment to upgrading its foundation model architecture and developing agentic AI capabilities within Weixin, which we believe could yield notable investment return in the future. Looking ahead, with solid grossing from a growing number of evergreen titles, upgraded ad platform and AI cloud infrastructure, we believe the growth trajectory across segments is clear and convincing. ● Alibaba (BABA.N/9988.HK; Buy; TP US$225/HK$223) - Core AI Play – We have a Buy rating on BABA with SOTP TPs of US$225/HK$223. We continue to view BABA as one of the best

AI plays for China AI exposure. We believe BABA is well-positioned to capture the AI evolution that should translate to sustainable cloud revs growth with efficiency margin upside in the coming years. Leveraging its strong AI capabilities, including Qwen model, multi-modal cloud infrastructure and strong traction across industry enterprises in China, we expect Ali Cloud revs to sustain strong growth in the coming quarters following decent reaccelerated growth in the past 6 quarters. We expect synergies between Shangou and marketplaces to bring more resilient CMR growth despite lapse of fee and a higher base and a decent EBITA rebound post the heavy investment stage. ● Trip.com (TCOM; Buy; TP US$86) - Sustainable earnings growth – We remain positive on TCOM amid resilient China travel demand and strong momentum for Trip.com. The recent recovery of the hotel industry should present tailwinds for the domestic business, while outbound has shown decent trajectory despite normalizing base. Trip.com is performing better than our previous expectation thanks to strong enhancement on user engagement along with product and service upgrade. We remain relatively

optimistic over TCOM’s margin trajectory ahead thanks to its more disciplined spending on both the China and int’l businesses. Maintain Buy with a TP of US$86. 12

China Internet: Sector Top Picks (continued) ● NetEase (NTES; Buy; TP US$161) – Sustainable Earnings Growth – We like NetEase for its proven operation and execution track record in developing and publishing high-quality, longevity game franchise titles. Not only is the company able to continue maintaining and achieving record grossing momentum of evergreen FWJ PC and FWJ Mobile, it also consistently delivers growing evergreen franchises with increasing global success such as Where Wind Meets and Sword of Justice. Its renewed and deepened operational success of Blizzard titles further proves its localization and publishing strengths. Entering 2026, with steady and resilient grossing from flagship evergreen titles, together with upcoming release of Ananta, we believe NTES’s gaming portfolio performance could further strengthen. Together with solid execution and stable shareholder return and undemanding valuation, we maintain a Buy rating and TP of US$161. ● J&T Express (1519.HK; Buy; TP HK$12) – Derivative international exposure

– J&T Express remains our top pick for the China logistics sector. With a stabilizing China earnings outlook, J&T Express is gaining strong momentum in SEA driven by solid performance of its key customers and J&T’s further wallet share gains thanks to its competitive edges vs. peers. We also see decent potential in New Markets where J&T is enjoying rapid expansion of its Chinese customers and penetrating into local ecommerce platforms. Maintain Buy with a TP of HK$12. ● Century Huatong (002602.SZ; Buy; TP Rmb22) – A-share preferred pick – We expect near-term catalysts to include its upcoming 12-month buyback program at Rmb0.5-1bn likely from late Nov, potential media ETF/index inclusion by mid-Dec and possible newflows from HK Stock Connect and margin trading should provide some price support. We also expect solid and resilient performance of Whiteout Survival and Kingshot entering 4Q25/1Q26. With new hires from Century Games mainly focusing on new game

development, we expect Century Huatong to continue to actively invest in global strategy and casual game markets and see current valuation as attractive with decent enhanced buying opportunity. Maintain Buy with TP Rmb22, based on 20x 2026E PE. 13

 2025 was an inflection year for China AI sentiment thanks to the “DeepSeek” moment in end-Jan. As noted in our 4Q24 wrap , it triggered transformation including reversal of investor sentiment towards the China market and valuations, especially for internet giants with an AI angle like BABA and Tencent; and fast adoption of AI assistant chatbots by a vast number of consumers and deployment of LLM models across big and small enterprises across many industries and government departments. In addition, we also noticed a shift in capital allocation towards prioritizing investment in AI while shareholder returns for some companies slowed. And investors had higher tolerance for core business performance as long as the AI story looked promising.  Heading into 2026, while the debate on whether we are in an AI valuation “bubble” or not rages on, we believe China internet stocks could close the valuation gap although they might remain at discounts vs global peers amid geopolitical uncertainty and AI supply chain constraints. That said, with the adoption speed brisk, we expect intense AI competition among China

players across AI infrastructure, AI assistant chatbots to AI applications in 2026, with monetization likely trailing user traffic growth and that of global peers. ■ The AI themes for China in 2026 are likely to be: 1) recurring revs growth of cloud infra/model stack/inference token usage (BABA, Baidu); 2) user traffic turf war between AI chatbots (Qwen, Doubao, Hunyuan) as key internet players (BABA, Bytedance, Tencent) rush to capture AI era traffic gateway for future ecosystem monetization; and 3) vertical players (Meituan, TCOM, Didi, etc), deploying their self-trained proprietary data AI agents to stay ahead of potential disruption and seeking to strengthen user engagement and monetization upside. We expect most internet companies to improve operating leverage through productivity gains from AI-assisted cost optimization, with some enjoying reacceleration of top-line growth thanks to effective AI agent deployment. Source: QuestMobile, Citi Research AI Cloud Infra, AI Assistant Chat & AI Agents

 Alibaba Cloud – During FY2Q26, cloud revs +34% yoy (+29% yoy excl. Ali-consolidated subsidiaries) and AI-related product revenue achieved triple-digit yoy growth for the 9th consecutive quarter. Over the past 4 quarters, Ali has deployed ~Rmb120bn in capex towards AI and cloud infrastructure. Mgmt noted that customer demand for cloud and AI services remains strong with its capacity still not enough to meet customer order volume growth, leading to stronger pent-up order demand for Alibaba Cloud. Mgmt highlighted their Rmb380bn capex plan mainly designed for a 3- year time horizon, and Alibaba Cloud may further invest actively in capex and GPU supply chain to fulfill customer demand as soon as possible (link ). ■ Tencent Cloud – In 3Q25, business services revs grew teens % yoy despite supply-chain constraints on sourcing GPUs, driven by cloud services and fees collected on Mini Shops ecommerce transactions. Management has highlighted notable

YoY growth in revenues from cloud storage and data management products. During the quarter, Tencent has enhanced Hunyuan LLM’s complex reasoning capabilities especially in coding, math and science. At the same time, Tencent aims to continue to strengthen the synergies between Weixin and Yuanbao by launching multiple AI features on Weixin powered by Yuanbao. Mgmt believes it is possible that ultimately there would be an AI agent embedded within Weixin to help users achieve multiple missions within the Weixin ecosystem (link ). ■ Baidu AI Cloud – In 3Q25, AI cloud revs grew 21% yoy to Rmb6.2bn, including AI cloud infrastructure revenues reaching Rmb4.2bn, +33% yoy. Within AI cloud infrastructure, subscription-based AI accelerator infrastructure revenues grew 128% yoy, accelerating from around 50% last quarter. AI applications revenues amounted to Rmb2.6bn, including Baidu Wenku and Baidu Drive, where AI has enhanced the functionalities across these products. For AI native marketing services, which

include agents and digital humans, revenues reached Rmb2.8bn representing a robust 262% yoy increase and contributing 18% of Baidu’s core online marketing revenues, up from 4% a year ago. Altogether, revenue from AI-powered business grew over 50% yoy to roughly Rmb10bn in 3Q25. (link ).  TCOM – OTAs are actively integrating AIGC technologies into their operations. Beside coding development and customer service, the key area of adoption is the travel assistant for its users by leveraging capabilities from major LLMs. TCOM’s TripGenie is now used in more than 200 countries and regions, with related users growing over 200% yoy in 1H25, supporting interaction of audio and image, travel planning, real-time translation and booking service to enhance user engagement. Like TCOM, Tongcheng also rolled out an AI-driven travel planner, DeepTrip, in Mar 2025 to provide viable and personalized travel itineraries for users, attracting millions of users with a steadily increasing number of orders placed directly through the portal.  Meituan – Meituan is advancing its AI strategy by building capabilities in three core areas: self-developed large language models, AI productization, and AI infrastructure. The company has launched its open-source "Long Cat" series of self-trained LLMs, which have received positive feedback and are now deeply integrated into its applications to drive innovation. For

merchants, Meituan has upgraded AI tools like "Shangqitong" for product planning and site selection, and "Smart Shopkeeper" with new modules for AI reception, operational analysis, and review responses. For consumers, the company is testing both a standalone AI assistant, "Xiaomei", and an integrated assistant, "Ask Xiaotuan ", within the Meituan app, which can handle the entire service process from search and price comparison to order generation across all local service categories. Internally, Meituan is also developing AI programming tools to boost employee efficiency.  Didi – Didi has an AI Lab focus on machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, voice recognition, operations research and statistical studies, and has been focusing on investing in AI and self-driving technology. On Sep 25, 2025, Didi started to perform open beta testing of its AI travel assistant, “Xiao Di”, which is embedded in the Didi dispatch system which uses intelligent understanding of user needs to provide them with customized car service plans. While in early

stage, we believe that through its large volume of data and user traffic, applying AI tools could help Didi’s app stay relevant and provide personalized experience to its users.  As AI assistant tools support users’ productivity improvement at work and in their personal lives, users might have more time to spare for leisure and entertainment activities. We believe the gaming industry will likely see benefits from AI adoption.  Per CNG , in 2025, China’s online-game market reached Rmb350.8bn, +7.68% yoy, representing a new historical high from previous peak last year. Total gamer base in China reached 683mn, up 1.35% yoy, also a record high and implying monthly ARPU of Rmb42.8, +6.2% yoy. In 2025, the in-house developed domestic game market reached Rmb291.1bn, re-accelerating to +11.6% yoy, driven by stable evergreen titles and decent new games contribution. Mobile games re-accelerated to 7.9% yoy to Rmb257.1bn and contributed a slightly bigger mix at 73.3% share, setting another record high. Among top-100 mobile games, RPG accounted for a 20% mix (share -4% yoy), followed by strategy games at 11% (replacing card games as second

place) and card games at 8%.  Into 2026, we believe China’s online-gaming market is likely to experience sustainable growth driven by increasing adoption of generative-AI interactions and attractive gameplay, with the domestic ACG market likely rebounding with anticipated key new launches and expected overseas expansion motivated by continued strengthening of competitiveness.  We also believe the online gaming sector could remain the frontier for AIGC application in terms of productivity and efficiency gains in art design, content generation and further boost creativity such as AI NPC, AI companion and AI live-streaming features. Together with rich cash positions, generous shareholder returns and steady margin profiles, we believe the online gaming sector will likely generate a decent earnings profile entering 2026E with ample opportunities for further differentiation in the domestic market and a significant TAM from tapping into the overseas gamer base. Intense competition continues ■ Trade-in program extends in 2026 – We view the latest policy support for the extension of the trade-in program as a potential positive read-through for a majority of e-commerce platforms, to help cushion the high-base effect in 1H26. Despite the initial-batch subsidy amount of Rmb62.5bn and the maximum subsidy amount per unit being smaller for the 2026 trade-in program than for the 2025 program—along with fewer categories of eligible home appliances (6 vs. 12)—we believe on a net- net basis, it should still be viewed as a positive sentiment booster that could spur consumption. That said, given the very high base of comparison and the smaller subsidy size, we believe the overall benefit to JD.com and other ecommerce platforms is likely to be limited. While smart glasses are newly added to the products qualified for the subsidy, we believe the adoption rate could be limited. ■ Intensified ecommerce competition amid soft macros – Overall, we believe loss from food delivery/quick commerce

investment should have peaked in 3Q25 based on Alibaba and Meituan’s comments; uncertainties remain, though, as both companies unlikely want to be the one that scales back subsidy (which would benefit opponents). Hence, while we believe the magnitude of loss in 4Q25 and future quarters should be lower than in 3Q25, it remains uncertain when Meituan/industry could return to profitability. ■ Muted macros – As Dec likely faced an even tougher base for home appliance sales, we believe the trend could have negative read-through to JD’s overall 4Q25 growth. After the mid-Jan release of Dec sales data, we will need to wait until mid-Mar to get the Jan and Feb 2026 sales data, which we believe could remain muted read-through to the overall consumption trend. AI improves advertising efficiency; key sports events in 2026 ■ Market share gainers in 2025 – Performances varied significantly among advertising platforms in 2025, with clear market share gainers including Tencent, Kuaishou, and Bilibili achieving double-digit revenue growth for 9M25, while market share losses were incurred by Baidu, Weibo, iQiyi, Zhihu, and Sohu, which recorded year-on-year declines in revenues. Market share changes based on advertising revenues follows changes in traffic flow, AI applications, and user behavior amid the AI era. Additionally, amid the AI era, we expect potentially more budget shift to performance ads as advertisers demand high ROI. ■ AI effect growing – AI capabilities have supported ad eCPM and helped advertising efficiency, as noted by Tencent, Kuaishou, Weibo, etc. We expect online advertising platforms to continue to utilize AI to improve media distribution efficiency, consumer reach efficiency and advertising efficiency. ■ Intensified ecommerce competition helps advertising budgets – In 3Q25, 1) various advertising companies including Weibo

and Focus Media noted advertising revenue growth from ecommerce players due to step-up in competition in quick commerce, while Tencent noted increases in all categories during the quarter. Players like Weibo and Focus Media remained positive on e-commerce advertiser spending in 4Q25 due to continued competition in quick commerce. If ecommerce competition remains intense, we would expect advertising platforms to continue to enjoy the benefits, while a high base will start to kick in in 2Q26E as ecommerce competition started in 2Q25. ■ Key sports events in 2026 – Although macro uncertainties remain, entering 2026, key events including Winter Olympics in Feb 2026 and World Cup in Jun 2026 should contribute to advertising budgets, especially among categories such as FMCG, in our view. Resilient China travel with overseas expansion  China domestic travel demand has shown resilience with moderate volume growth and stabilizing pricing trajectory likely thanks to more household shifting spending towards experience consumption. We expect more normalized growth for the outbound industry ahead but still see decent room considering 1) merely >160mn Chinese owning effective passports vs. its total population of 1.4bn, and 2) friendly visa policies of more countries towards Chinese citizens.  Beside its China business, TCOM is expanding into APAC aggressively by leveraging its technologies and knowhow accumulated in China with rapid market share gains in major countries, becoming a LT growth story despite ST margin drag. Investment phase for offline performance players ■ Music concert box office in 2026E: stable – Due to the full capacity of venues for music concerts in tier 1 and tier 2 cities, we expect 2026 box office for music concerts to remain largely stable vs 2025. After three years post the pandemic, demand for music concerts remains strong, especially for top-tier artists’ concerts. However, as the domestic macro environment remains sluggish, we expect divergence in music concert project demand: continued strong demand for top-tier artists’ projects while demand for mid-to-low tier artists’ projects could see pressure in 2026E. Competition between Damai and Maoyan should remain stable as Maoyan aims to focus on investing in building key infrastructure as price wars lead to low ROI, while Damai’s leadership as the No.1 music concert ticketing platform remains solid. ■ Investment for future growth: overseas & music concert promotion business – Damai is investing in 1) overseas ticketing business; and 2) exploring to become a music concert promoter for international artists to host their Asia concert tours. In the

first stage, we expect Damai would need to cooperate with local music concert promoters in overseas market as it builds up capabilities. Investment in overseas market and music concert promotion business is likely to weigh on Damai’s near-term profit margin. For Maoyan, its key investment areas remain in the domestic market to compete with Damai in ticketing business. Maoyan has shifted to invest in core capabilities as a music concert ticketing platform, including 1) improving relationship with concert venues & event organizers; 2) ticketing system capabilities and technology improvement. ■ Offline performance players – Overall we remain cautious about music concert players (Damai and Maoyan) in 2026 due to limited growth opportunities in the domestic market amid full venue capacity & soft macro conditions, and the investment in overseas market should weigh on near-term margins. Upside risks include any top-tier artist concert project announcement. India Internet 2026 Outlook: Improving OpM & UE Executive Summary • In 2026, we expect the following themes to play out in the India internet space – (i) growth & competitive intensity in quick commerce should remain high, especially since all major players have raised funds recently & continue to see growth in both user-base and wallet-share. Having said that, given public equity considerations, we expect the leading players to continue to progress towards improved overall profitability, (ii) improvement in overall payments monetization across B2B and B2C for payments fintech, (iii) OTA rebound on supply-driven dynamics and sustained demand appetite/momentum, (iv) auto industry recovery leading to strong growth in auto classifieds, and (v) sustained pressure in job classifieds. • We expect most companies under coverage to continue to deliver significant expansion in operating margins, primarily driven by operating leverage but also improving unit economics/contribution margins in select companies like Swiggy and Paytm.

• While recent progress on labor law reforms has provided much needed clarity on gig economy regulatory regime, we continue to expect regulatory development in 2026, including a potential change in India’s laws pertaining to multi-brand retail FDI laws. Regulatory development in fintech is also likely to persist. Our top picks are Eternal and Makemytrip. Key Themes:  Intense competition in quick commerce: Zepto and Swiggy have raised or are raising significant fresh capital. Quick commerce will likely continue to see sustained competitive intensity. However, given public equity considerations, we also expect leading companies to continue to push towards better unit economics and higher overall profitability. In FY27E, we believe growth investments will increasingly shift towards dark-store and supply chain investments. However, we expect new user acquisition spending to remain high as well, attendant with the geographic expansion in quick commerce presence.  Fintech: PayTm ramps up as regulatory burden eases: As Paytm reboots its consumer payments business after receiving the payment aggregator license in

Aug’25, the company can leverage its relative scale and product development capabilities to be more competitive vs earlier. We expect the company to continue expanding across all segments (payment segment – online merchant expansion and credit card on UPI, financial services – postpaid offerings, equity broking arm, and international business).  OTA rebound likely in sight: We expect the sector to see growth rebound in 2HFY26 and FY27 driven by easing of supply side issues and strong travel sentiment. Traffic and high frequency air traffic data points to recovery in domestic passenger traffic. Also, airlines have set bold targets for medium term.  Auto classifieds riding macro tailwinds: Cartrade has seen solid growth on the back of GST cuts, rising digital penetration in auto ad spend. We expect the same to continue in FY26 and FY27 as the Indian auto sector has become more competitive with all major OEMs planning a slew of model launches over the next 2-3 years. Auto classifieds space is likely to be a key beneficiary as OEMs try to win market share through ad spend.

 Continued weakness in job classifieds: The growth outlook for Indian IT, which forms a big chunk of hiring on job classifieds platforms (esp. Naukri), has remained muted. We expect sustained headwinds in IT, given the deflationary impact of AI on headcounts. Global Capability Center (GCC) hiring remained resilient in 2025 for Naukri owing to the lagged impact of GCC expansion, although GCC hiring could see pressure from the deflationary impact of GenAI in FY27E. Non-IT outlook could improve as a function of domestic macroeconomic growth. Regulations:  Given the growth in quick commerce and its impact on other retail channels, specifically on general trade, we expect regulatory scrutiny to increase on platforms on issues including pricing strategies. In the fintech space, we expect sustained regulatory bent towards limiting aggressive growth in retail unsecured loans, but we don’t expect any regulatory tightening on merchant categories. 2026 could see more clarity around implementation of labor law

reforms for gig workers announced in Nov’25. Source: Company data, Citi Research 25 India Internet: Preferred Picks for 2026 • Eternal (Buy; ETEA.BO; TP Rs440) - While competition is heating up in quick commerce, we believe Eternal remains firmly in the pole position with its House of Brands strategy, focus on leadership across the key vectors of convenience (highest dark store footprint) and selection (widest SKU selection). Its solid cash balance is also a strength as it allows the company to defend market share in quick commerce. In food delivery, Zomato’s growth recovered in the recent quarter and the company has consistently gained market share in the past 2-3 years and is firmly on course to achieve medium-term margin guidance with potential to exceed, in our view. In both these key categories, the runway for growth remains high and Eternal’s execution track record has been strong. • MakeMyTrip (Buy; MMYT.O; TP US$108) - While travel demand saw murkiness in 1HFY26, primarily due to uncertain geopolitics and

supply side constraints, structurally the sector remains resilient. MMYT has strong positioning as a platform with solid domestic and international leisure travel capabilities. We believe MMYT is well positioned to benefit from a) easing of supply-side constraints in the domestic market and improving low-cost connectivity in air travel, and b) its own initiatives to expand channel capabilities (B2B, B2B2C), increase direct contracting with international hotels, etc. in hotel reservations. The competitive environment has remained benign in the space and has allowed MMYT to steadily expand margins/profitability. We believe MMYT has decent growth tailwinds + margins have significant potential to expand further, driven by operating leverage. Source: Citi Research Top Buys Top Sells • Info Edge (Sell; INED.BO; TP Rs1,300) - While INED has commanding market leadership in the recruitment business, IT hiring in India is facing significant headwinds from GenAI, and the non-IT hiring outlook is relatively weak in FY26E given muted intent in key

sectors like BFSI. Other verticals are more competitive compared to recruitment, and growth/profitability in the non-recruitment verticals is only improving at a modest pace. While key investee companies are seeing solid growth and form a substantial part of INED's SOTP, we believe the slowing growth (and potential medium-term growth challenges) in core business is a major headwind. • Nykaa (Sell; FSNE.BO; TP Rs175) - While Nykaa has seen a strong growth trajectory in FY25 and 1HFY26, we find valuations very expensive. Our multiple for Nykaa is at par with our multiple for Eternal’s Online Food Delivery (FD) business. We believe par multiple is justified given EBITDA to PAT translation is better in FD vs for Nykaa. Nykaa trades at 76x FY27E EV/EBITDA and 115x EV/EBIT on our estimates which make it difficult to get constructive. 26

Korea Internet Outlook 28 Pawl Hwang paul1.hwang@citi.com +82 2 3705-0748 Josh Yang josh .yang@citi.com +82 2 3705-0723 Heejin Lim heejin.lim@citi.com +82 2 3705-0768 Jimin Cha jimin.cha@citi.com +82 2 3705-0741

Coupang’s solid position in a growing ecommerce market is likely to continue ■ Ecommerce penetration rate continues to increase where we forecast ex-auto / ex-fuel e-commerce penetration rate in Korea to further increase to 38% in 2027, from 32%/35% in 2023/25E. ■ Coupang’s M/S to further increase where we forecast Coupang’s M/S within ecommerce segment to increase to 27% in 2027E from 18%/24% in 2023/25E, while Coupang’s M/S within the food delivery segment could increase to 34% in 2027E from 6%/23% in 2023/25E. ■ Naver & Kakao taking different approaches in search ad market – While Naver has increased exposure of its AI-based search summary feature (AI Briefing) to 20% at end-2025 to maintain / defend its leadership in the Korea search ad market, ChatGPT integration in Kakaotalk is designed to capture transition in search behavior, i.e., illustrating Kakao’s push into the search ad market.

■ Stock view – We have Buy on Coupang (CPNG.N), given: 1) continued increase in ecommerce penetration rate in Korea; 2) continued market share gains by Coupang within the Korea ecommerce segment, leading to better scalability; and 3) likely no major negative impact from Coupang’s recent customer information data leakage issue (excluding one-off customer compensation package / government penalty). We have Sell rating on Naver (035420.KS), given: 1) rising competition from ChatGPT in Korea’s search market; 2) Naver’s other verticals are likely to face competition in the future as well; and 3) non- core overseas asset acquisition (such as Wallapop in 2025). Major drivers in 2026E to be mega IP, rookie IP & localized IP monetization ■ Major drivers in 26E – We see following major events / factors as key drivers of K-pop in 2026E, including: 1) comeback of mega IP (BTS by HYBE, EXO by SM) and continued monetization of mega IP (BlackPink by YG); 2) acceleration in monetization of rookie IP such as BabyMonster (YG), Cortis (HYBE), NCT WISH (SM); and 3) localized IP’s successful execution in the western market (Katseye by HYBE, Girlset by JYP). ■ Upside catalysts – Potential positive catalysts for the K-pop industry: 1) favorable Korea-China relations leading to more frequent concert sales; and 2) better-than-expected ramp-up of merchandise sales following expansion of concert / album sales in virtuous cycles. ■ Downside catalysts – Potential negative catalysts for the K-pop industry: 1) negative spillover from unofficial ban of

Japanese/Chinese artists in counterparty markets due to continued political tension; and 2) lower-than-expected mega IP take rates deteriorating the margin outlook for future mega IPs. ■ Stock view – We have Neutral rating on HYBE (352820.KS), JYP Entertainment (035900.KQ), SM Entertainment (041510.KQ) and YG Entertainment (122870.KQ). That said, HYBE is our relative preferred pick, as we believe it has the strongest potential to enjoy all three major growth pillars (mega IP comeback, rookie IP monetization and localized IP execution) in 2026E. Risks to HYBE are unfavorable take rate with BTS and/or NewJeans IP seeing revision. Navigating structural headwinds and visibility risks ■ Remain selective – We remain selective on the Korea gaming sector given [1] structural headwind amid intensifying competition on time & wallet share from non-gaming apps, [2] Korea gaming industry’s heavy tilt towards the mobile RPG segment, and [3] visibility risk amid continued delay of major pipeline games, such as Crimson Desert (Pearl Abyss). On a positive note, if AI capability is materially adopted in game development, especially in areas such as graphic/animation generation and programming, we believe it could lead to significant cost-cutting as well as potential shortening of the game development cycle (although timing of meaningful AI adoption among Korean game developers remains uncertain). ■ Top pick – Among Korean game developers, we prefer Krafton, supported by its resilient user engagement and greater potential to diversify monetization. We also think its longer-term strategies are well positioned to sustain user traffic and engagement, with the roll-out of new modes, UGC features, and Unreal Engine 5. We believe investors’ concern on aggressive

investment, new hire and intensifying competition have been largely priced in at a 2026E PE multiple of 11x. On the other hand, we remain cautious on Pearl Abyss on continued execution risk amid repeated delays in the launch of Crimson Desert, which was first unveiled in 2019. Source: Citi Research, Business of Apps, data.ai, Sensor Tower Korea Gaming: Remain Selective Non-gaming vs. gaming app global revenue in 16-25 Krafton: Revenue and OPM Outlook 31 Japan Internet Outlook 32 Keiichi Yoneshima Keiichi.yoneshima@citi.com +81 3 6776-8033 Tokiya Baba tokiya.baba@citi.com +81 3 6776-4618

Japan Internet Sector ■ Online advertising: AI changing the game; staffing ads on the rise – We believe the online advertising market could continue to grow. We expect demand for search ads to stagnate or even contract because of the spread of AI. Meanwhile, in video ads and the like, we think the use of AI will increase the efficiency of ad creation. While the product mix is changing, the online advertising market should remain solid. ■ Ecommerce: “Cruising speed” conditions – Although the ecommerce market seems mature, we look for mid-single-digit growth. We expect AI-powered recommendations to encourage purchasing but also think the macroeconomic environment and trends in disposable income will require monitoring. ■ Online games: Profitability improving, but new hits still the catalysts – In online games, we expect the spread of external payments (which have already been introduced for some games) to increase profitability. Although we believe the appeal of existing major titles could increase, we think new hit titles will continue to be needed for the market to take a constructive view.

■ Still some time before AI increases profitability – Many companies in our coverage are using AI to promote efficient development and cost efficiency is improving. AI-powered services are still in the trial stages, so increased profitability is still some way off. Source: Citi Research Japan Internet/Game: AI a Blessing and a Curse/Growth Driven by Global IPs Japan Game Sector ■ Leveraging global IP to capture incremental demand in the industry – We forecast that continued new releases for both console and mobile games could lead to increased overall demand for software, intensifying competition within the industry. In this environment, the ownership of global IP will likely become a key point. We anticipate that users could be increasingly drawn to software titles that leverage global IP. ■ Identifying stocks with high earnings visibility – With the rise in share prices across the sector over the past few years, some stocks have stretched P/E, in our view. Accordingly, distinguishing between companies that can continue to achieve EPS growth as expected by the market and those that cannot will be key. The release of new software titles directly contributes to repeat sales

momentum, making it a key indicator of the visibility of profit growth going forward. 33

■ Double-digit growth at Indeed US increasingly likely — When Recruit reported FY3/26 Q2 results it announced it will use US ASP growth rate as a KPI for Indeed US. This suggests a shift in the earnings model for the company’s job search business from a quantity-based model (clicks x unit price) to a quality-based model (aiming to increase the unit price by improving job-matching accuracy). We believe this pivot to improved quality and the setting of simple KPIs have made Recruit’s strategy clearer and increased confidence in the company’s growth. We think Indeed US is the driver of Recruit’s earnings and believe the market’s evaluation could improve as Indeed US returns to double-digit growth. ■ Leveraging AI technology to yield benefits — Since 2023 Indeed has been working with OpenAI to promote the use of AI technology in the HR field. Indeed has already begun introducing AI-powered services on both the company and customer sides. HR technology companies (including Indeed US) are reducing costs through the use of AI in program coding. While we

cannot dismiss the possibility that companies possessing the AI technology itself could become competitors in the HR field, Indeed and Recruit specialize in HR, and their expertise and accumulated data are rare and valuable information that other companies likely lack. The ability to utilize such data is an advantage and we think the company could maintain superiority by leveraging both its vast amount of HR data and AI technology. ■ Staffing ad volume showing signs of bottoming out — JOLTS (an index of US staffing ad volume) has been in a steady decline since 2022. Although the downtrend continued in 2025, the index was flat YoY in September and October, suggesting that it is bottoming out. Although Recruit is doing all it can to switch to a revenue model unaffected by the direction of staffing ad volume, a bottoming of staffing ad volume should be a positive, in our view. ■ Valuation — Our DCF model-based target price is ¥11,000. We believe the concerns are amply priced in with the shares down c20% (as of December 19 close) from the November 6 peak, having corrected to a lower level than at the NS2 launch. ■ Launch of major first party titles in 2026 for potential rerating — The key we see from here is improvement in momentum via the launch of high-ASP/high-margin first party titles and we therefore look to “Nintendo Direct”, when Nintendo unveils its new titles, as a likely trigger for rerating . Rising penetration rate & spending drive structural growth yet attracting more competition ■ SEA as AI datacenter hub – Thanks to its neutral/interconnected position between the US and China, vibrant demographic and availability of energy resources and sufficient geographic landscape, we believe Southeast Asia possesses suitable criteria to attract investment from the US and Chinese hyperscale operators as their regional data center hub. Higher investment funding will likely fuel employment opportunities and growing income, which could translate to higher spending power by consumers over time that supports structural growth opportunities of the digital economy. ■ Competition intensifies – In ecommerce, we expect competition between Shopee and TikTok to likely get more intense in 2026, especially if TikTok Shop further expands its ecommerce offerings to shelf-based/marketplace model on top of live- streaming, and any bigger ambition of integrating its AI Chatbot assistant with ecommerce that could threaten and disrupt ecommerce and other services in the AI era will be something to watch for. ■ AI and autonomous driving testing – We expect to hear increasing comments from industry players including Grab and Sea

to discuss and share their investment philosophy in AI and how they expect AI to amplify their growth outlook and margin upside. While it remains in early stages, we expect Grab to pursue its autonomous driving testing in SG and possibly other cities in SEA and commit investment to AI and autonomous driving technology to embrace the new technology and be the leader in helping the society to prepare for the inclusion of robotaxi transition. ■ Market consolidation – If media reports on a possible revival of Grab/GoTo deal materialize in 2026, we would expect potential positive synergies to industry sentiment, subsidies reduction, moderating competitive landscape and improving industry margin as well as strengthening of Grab’s on-demand market positioning in SEA. Source: Google, Temasek, Bain & Company, Citi Research ASEAN Internet: Structural Growth & Competition SEA digital economy GMV breakdown (US$bn) SEA ecommerce GMV (US$bn) SEA food delivery GMV (US$bn) 37

■ Solid mobility momentum — 3Q25 mobility GMV reached US$2.04bn, up 20% yoy, accelerating from 16.6% in 1Q25 and 18.9% in 2Q25, attributed to 17% yoy growth in mobility MTUs and 11% growth in average ride frequency per user, leading to total mobility transaction growth of 30% yoy, outpacing GMV growth. We believe the solid demand growth came from Grab’s successful affordability strategy where GrabBike and GrabCar Saver help satisfy lower-end demand while GrabExecutive and GrabPremium help serve the wealthy and higher-ASP customer. We model 4Q25 GMV to +17.6% yoy with EBITDA margin relatively stable at 8.85%. Steady stage EBITDA margin profile remains unchanged at 9%+. ■ Improving deliveries strength — Deliveries GMV accelerated to +26% yoy (22% c. currency) in 3Q25 thanks to a widening user base via affordability, deepening engagement with successful cross-selling and traction of new product initiatives

including group orders, Mart and GrabMore. As users who use both food and grocery services demonstrated 1.8x higher order frequency than food-only users, we expect GMV contribution from GrabMart to grow from current 10% of deliveries to a higher % over time, especially GrabMart which serves as an important driver of better user retention and customer loyalty as well as higher chance to grow advertising revs from FMCG clients. We model 4Q25/2026 GMV to +19.6%/18.5% yoy with EBITDA margin at 2.09%/2.33%. Grab reiterates deliveries segment to achieve steady stage EBITDA margin profile of 4%+. ■ GrabFin and Digibanks — Grab targets to achieve >US$1bn in loan book net of expected credit loss provision at exit 2025 and to achieve EBITDA breakeven in 2H26 for DFS segment. Digibanks continue to gain strong traction with customer deposits across GXS Bank (SG) and GX Bank (MY) +20% YoY to US$1.3bn at the end of 3Q25 and Superbank in IN saw

deposit customer +20% qoq to reach another all-time high at the end of Sep 2025. ■ SOTP at US$7.20 — We value Grab at US$30.4bn based on 1) 19.x on 2026E adjusted EBITDA for the combined on-demand business; 2) 6x 2026E IFRS revs for financial services and 3) 25% discount on 3Q25 cash. Source: Company report, Citi Research estimates Grab (Buy; TP US$7.20) Grab – On-demand deliveries and mobility GMV and yoy growth Grab – Segment adjusted EBITDA and margin % 38

Source: Company report, Citi Research Estimates Goto (Buy/HR; TP Rp110.0) All eyes on possible merger with Grab, without this expectation the share price of Goto could be under pressure.  Leadership change may suggest revival of deal outlook: We believe the appointment of new CEO Hans Patuwo (effective after Dec 17, 2025 EGMS approval) likely signals a pivot towards operational focus and may re-open Grab merger discussions. Patuwo’s appointment, backed by major shareholders, may signal readiness to explore a transformative consolidation, in our view (link ).  Strategic rationale – scale & synergy: A potential Grab–GoTo combination would create a dominant Southeast Asia platform (~85–90% ride-hailing market share in key markets), unlocking significant cost efficiencies and scale benefits. The merged entity would help streamline duplicative operations and gain stronger bargaining power (e.g. in fleet procurement and

technology). Platform synergies would be sizeable: integrating GoTo’s strengths in two-wheeler mobility and e-commerce (Tokopedia) with Grab’s four-wheeler network and delivery logistics would enhance service breadth.  Government support & regulatory outlook: The Indonesian government has openly encouraged a potential merger. A cabinet minister confirmed talks are underway and indicated the state’s sovereign wealth fund (Danantara) may take a minority stake in the combined entity. This involvement would safeguard national interests and help address anti- competition concerns, easing regulatory approval by ensuring consumers and drivers are protected. (Link 1 ; Link 2 )  Timing expectations: Should negotiations progress, we believe a realistic deal timeline would be 1H 2026 or later, allowing time for due diligence, definitive agreements, and regulatory review. Investors should watch for early-2026 developments when the companies would likely navigate shareholder approvals and antitrust clearances if a deal progresses.

 Goto Financial could be major share price driver: GoPay exceeded 500 million transactions/month (+54% YoY) with 24 million monthly active users (+29% YoY) as of 9M25. A standalone GoPay app, launched in 2023, is accelerating mass- market adoption beyond major cities. GTF is also leveraging strategic partnerships – e.g. a 22% stake in Bank Jago to offer banking services via GoPay – to convert unbanked users and deepen engagement.  Profitability milestones: Aggressive cost control and operational efficiency measures underpinned GoTo’s first-ever adjusted pre-tax profit in Q3 2025 (Rp62 billion). Management raised full-year 2025 adjusted EBITDA guidance to Rp1.8–1.9 trillion (up from Rp1.4–1.6 trillion) on this momentum. GTF’s improving margins and scalable growth are central to sustaining profitability, as the company continues its disciplined spending and monetization of its fintech user base. 39

Data current as of 01 Jan 2026 Buy Hold Sell Buy Hold Sell Citi Research Global Fundamental Coverage (Neutral=Hold) 60% 32% 8% 37% 47% 16% % of companies in each rating category that are investment banking clients 36% 40% 28% 40% 34% 35% Guide to Citi Research Fundamental Research Investment Ratings: Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. Risk rating takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned. Investment Ratings: Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of 15% or more or 25% or more for High risk stocks; and

Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign “Rating

Citi Research Suspended” status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as “—“ and “-“ respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned “Under Review” status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-

term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk. Catalyst Watch/Short Term Views (“STV”) Ratings Disclosure: Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near-term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified

30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds 15% against the direction of the call (unless over-ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock’s fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer-term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings-distribution-disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution-disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our

Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share-price movement will not materialize as expected.
